There are two sections A and B in an examination. The probabilities that Ronald passes section A and section B are 0.6 and 0.4 respectively. If Ronald passes section B, the probability that he passes section A is 0.72. Candidates are required to pass both section A and section B in order to pass the examination.
(a) Find the probability that Ronald passes the examination.
(b) Given that Ronald passes section A, which one is greater, the probability that he passes the examination or the probability that he does not pass the examination? Explain your answer.

quote.msg:
There are two sections A and B in an examination. The probabilities that Ronald passes section A and section B are 0.6 and 0.4 respectively. If Ronald passes section B, the probability that he passes section A is 0.72. Candidates are required to pass both section A and section B in order to pass the examination.
(a) Find the probability that Ronald passes the examination.
(b) Given that Ronald passes section A, which one is greater, the probability that he passes the examination or the probability that he does not pass the examination? Explain your answer.

replies.msg:
a)
P(pass the exam)=P(pass A and B)
P(A)=0.6
P(B)=0.4
P(AlB)=0.72
P(pass the exam)=0.4x0.72=0.288

b)
The probability that he does not pass the examination is greater.
Since the probability that he only passes section A is 0.6-0.288=0.312.
0.312>0.288.

(a) Find the probability that Ronald passes the examination.

a)

b)

(a) Find the probability that Ronald passes the examination.
(b) Given that Ronald passes section A, which one is greater, the probability that he passes the examination or the probability that he does not pass the examination? Explain your answer.

a)

replies.msg:
b)
The probability that he does not pass the examination is greater.
Since the probability that he only passes section A is (0.6-0.288)/0.6=0.52. Which greater than the probability(0.48) that he passes the exam given that he already passed section A.

係咪要咁樣?

replies.msg:
1. All oxides of Group I metals are water-soluble.

2. Number of neutrons in 60Ni (atomic number = 28) = 60 - 28 = 32
Option (A): Number of neutrons in 64Zn (atomic number = 30) = 64 - 30 = 34
Option (B): Number of neutrons in 62Ni (atomic number = 28) = 62 - 28 = 34
Option (C): Number of neutrons in 59Co (atomic number = 27) = 59 - 27 = 32
Option (D): Number of neutrons in 55Mn (atomic number = 25) = 55 - 25 = 30
